Subject: Re: [junit] How do i check if i am getting right output
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12653864; y=ZJ5GDvXJi3s88McfcZ7h3qOT9VO9kVU6NAlNhbsK0xGjEanH

Chris Dollin wrote:

> It is sufficient if such things exist, "standard" or not, on
> platforms supporting Java, "modern" or not. 

No, it is not sufficient though it might perhaps be necessary. 
Sufficiency would also require that Java had an API that could recognize 
these things. It doesn't. To Java, files are byte sequences, nothing more.

> The program says "read [or write] the next K bytes down this
> stream". If "this stream" happened to be connected to a record-
> oriented file, Java should do exactly what the program says -
> which is to invoke the filing-system call appropriate to writing 
> to that file, I would have thought, not just splattering the
> bytes randomly into the file's blocks.

Nothing's random. It puts the data where the program says to put the 
data, but it always treats the file as a sequence of bytes. Every API in 
Java for file access--FileInputStream, RandomAccessFile, FileChannel, 
etc.--sees the file as a contiguous sequence of bytes. Any notion of 
record boundary is in the application logic, not the Java library.

> [Which is why Jena's RDF/XML writer uses line.separator at a
>  critical point; we had been generating RDF/XML that some 
>  application running on Windows Did Not Like. Having the user
>  change it to a Modern Application wasn't an option.]

You may not realize it, but this risks creating malformed XML when your 
library is used on certain IBM platforms. These things happen when you 
write to platform defaults that can be in active conflict with the 
requirements of the format or protocol you're writing.
